title: Iris albomarginata
text:
Iris albomarginata is a species in the genus "<a href="Iris%20%28plant%29">Iris</a>", in the subgenus <a href="Iris%20subg.%20Scorpiris">"Scorpiris"</a>. It is a <a href="bulbous">bulbous</a> <a href="perennial%20plant">perennial</a>, from the mountains in the former <a href="USSR">Russian</a> states of <a href="Kyrgyzstan">Kyrgyzstan</a> and <a href="Tajikistan">Tajikistan</a>.
Description.
It has bright blue flowers with a white crest. It sometimes has yellow marks on the crest. The falls area white with a yellow centre.
It has 2-5 flowers on a short stem.
It flowers in March–April.
It has smooth dark green leaves between 1 and 2 cm wide and the plant reaches 30 cm (1 ft) in height. It also has a bright white edging to all the leaves. The stem is just visible behind the leaves.
Taxonomy.
It was first described by (Russian botanist <a href="Boris%20Fedtschenko">Boris Fedtschenko</a>) in Bulletin de <a href="Pierre%20Edmond%20Boissier">l'Herbier Boissier</a>, <a href="https%3A//www.biodiversitylibrary.org/page/33641879">page 917</a> in 1904. But it was called "Iris coerulea". When <a href="Michael%20Foster%20%28physiologist%29">Foster</a> was working on irises, he found that "Iris coerulea" was used to name an "<a href="Iris%20pumila">Iris pumila</a>" hybrid. He then renamed the iris as "Iris albomarginata" because the leaves of the iris had a white edging. This edging was a characteristic of several of the species in the "Scorpiris" subgenus section of irises.
It was then re-published as "Iris albomarginata" in 'Contributions from the <a href="Harvard%20University%20Herbaria">Gray Herbarium</a>' of <a href="Harvard%20University">Harvard University</a> in 1936.
"Iris albomarginata" is an accepted name by the <a href="Royal%20Horticultural%20Society">RHS</a>.
Native.
Found in <a href="Central%20Asia">Central Asia</a> (within the <a href="Tien%20Shan">Tien Shan</a> and <a href="Fergana%20Range">Fergana mountains</a>) and the <a href="Alay%20Mountains">Alayskiy</a> in Kyrgyzstan and Tajikistan. It is found on the clay and stone foothills at 2000m above sea level.
Cultivation.
It is <a href="Hardiness%20%28plants%29">hardy</a> to <a href="USDA">USDA</a> Zone: 4.
In the UK, it is better grown in an <a href="Alpine%20house">Alpine house</a> or <a href="bulb%20frame">bulb frame</a>.
Several specimens can be found in <a href="Royal%20Botanic%20Garden%20Edinburgh">Royal Botanic Garden Edinburgh</a>.
Propagation.
Irises can generally be propagated by <a href="Division%20%28horticulture%29">division</a>, or by seed growing.
Toxicity.
Like many other irises, most parts of the plant are poisonous (rhizome and leaves), if mistakenly ingested can cause stomach pains and vomiting. Also handling the plant may cause a skin irritation or an allergic reaction.
